texts.definition: Game elements used to provide actions, or make them easier to perform, in game worlds.
markups: <style="Definition">Game elements used to provide actions, or make them easier to perform, in game worlds.</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> are game elements that enable players' avatars and units to perform actions better that usual, or perform actions otherwise unavailable to them. By being separate entities that can exist independently of avatars or units, <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> can be designed so that they can be picked up, dropped, destroyed, traded, and so on.

Roleplaying games <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20and%20Dragons">Dungeons and Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/H%C3%A2rnmaster">HÃ¢rnmaster</link></style> make intense use of <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style>, often in the form of weapons and armors to affect combat.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> includes detailed rules for <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> that give bonuses to various skills if the player characters have them, and have entire source books dedicated to <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> and other game items<ref name="lt"/><ref name="ht"/><ref name="ut"/> (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20and%20Dragons">Dungeons and Dragons</link></style> have these as well<ref name="vault"/><ref name="vault2"/>).

Weapons are common <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> in many computer games, including <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>. While also doing this, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%20series">Team Fortress series</link></style>, through dispensers and sentry guns respectively, allow players to create <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> that can act independently in combat, needing only to be resupplied. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ultima%20Online">Ultima Online</link></style> also have various <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> to support crafting and farming. Players of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Just%20Cause%202">Just Cause 2</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Legend%20of%20Zelda:%20The%20Wind%20Waker">The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker</link></style> (and some mods and expansions for the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style>) can find grappling hooks that allow players to move by swinging.

Besides the design choices available to all <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, the fundamental characteristic of <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> are which actions they support. They can support actions by giving <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style>, either through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Buffs">Buffs</link></style> or through increases in <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, or by giving <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> that may also be <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>. They can also change the risks of <style="Link"><link="critical-failures">Critical Failures</link></style> and the chances of <style="Link"><link="critical-successes">Critical Successes</link></style>. A common functional type of <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> are <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style> to allow or affect <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, or dictate how <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> is done in <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> (but some <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> are meant as diegetic tools but can be used as improvised <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>). Maybe not too surprising given this, <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> allowing the regain of <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style> are also common. Although not always perceived as <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style>, game items such as keys, id cards, etc., that allow access to <style="Link"><link="conditional-passageways">Conditional Passageways</link></style> may be even more common that <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style> even if they may not be used as often. Other <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> allow or affect <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Farming">Farming</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style> (e.g. grappling hooks in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Just%20Cause%202">Just Cause 2</link></style>). Effects more specific that <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> can have is allowing <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style> to be activated, <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> to be exploited, or <style="Link"><link="alarms">Alarms</link></style> to be turned off (or on). Types of <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> defined by being noticeable game elements in their own right in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> include <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="self-service-kiosks">Self-Service Kiosks</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style>. The use of <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> can be designed so it require player actions to be successfully completed, e.g. <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style>.

Where and when they can be acquired is an important consideration regarding <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style>, and may make places into <style="Link"><link="resource-locations">Resource Locations</link></style>. This may be modified by <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style>, and this is especially common for <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> to replenish <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>. Besides what actions are affected and how common the <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> are, several other design options exist regarding <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style>. One is which <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> can use the <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style>, possibly controlled by the presence or absence <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>. Another option is which begin with them, and this can be more important for <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> than other <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> if <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> can use them as well. A third option relate to adding <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> considerations by linked the use of <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> to the consumption of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, the activation of <style="Link"><link="cooldown">Cooldown</link></style> periods, or their <style="Link"><link="deterioration">Deterioration</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> that only can be used once are quite closely related to <style="Link"><link="power-ups">Power-Ups</link></style> but differ in that players can choose when to used them - the most common case of this type of <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> are probably those that restore <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>. Limited numbers of uses and <style="Link"><link="deterioration">Deterioration</link></style> are ways of ensuring that the <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> provide <style="Link"><link="temporary-abilities">Temporary Abilities</link></style>, but this may also happen due to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style> if they are <style="Link"><link="transferable-items">Transferable Items</link></style>. While not as commonly used as <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>, unique <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> can be part of the <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="endgame-quests">Endgame Quests</link></style> to provide those in <style="Link"><link="endgame">Endgame</link></style> phases with the chance of improving the actions supported by the <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style>.

Finally, game designers need to consider if the usage of several <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> together simultaneously should be allowed, and if so if it should give rise to <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style>.

Although not as common as for <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style> or the more specialized <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> of <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> can be used to create <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style>. Likewise, <style="Link"><link="equipment-slots">Equipment Slots</link></style> can be assigned to particular types of <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> but this is probably most present through such slots for what <style="CurrentLink">Tool</style> or <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapon</link></style> one holds in one's hand.

<style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> are a way of providing <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> without breaking <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>. Maintaining <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> can also be used to explain restrictions of where one can acquire <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style>, e.g. only through certain <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>. This can also be used to regulate who can used them also without noticing that <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> can provide sensory abilities besides providing improved or new types of actions, and this makes them have strong link to a game's interface. Examples include ordinary binoculars (found for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout:%20New%20Vegas">Fallout: New Vegas</link></style>), sniper scopes (built-in into several weapons found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike">Counter-Strike</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Halo%20series">Halo series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style>), or more exotic equipment that provide <style="Link"><link="vision-modes">Vision Modes</link></style> (e.g. thermal sights in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Call%20of%20Duty%20series">Call of Duty series</link></style>).

For games with <style="Link"><link="live-action-roleplaying">Live Action Roleplaying</link></style>, the construction of game <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> may need to be the construction of functional <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> that can be used like any other non-game version or replicas that are indistinguishable from real <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style>. Any <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> that have physical representations or are assigned physical locations open up for making their proximity to other things into gameplay mechanics, i.e. <style="Link"><link="artifact-location-proximity">Artifact-Location Proximity</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="player-artifact-proximity">Player-Artifact Proximity</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> are <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> that change how <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> (all which may be <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>) work in games by being <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>. This through how they provide ways to temporarily or permanently provide <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>. For players, this may give <style="Link"><link="collecting">Collecting</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goals to acquire them and <style="Link"><link="facilitating-rewards">Facilitating Rewards</link></style> when receiving them. Depending on how common the <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> are, they may or not give <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, and when affected by <style="Link"><link="deterioration">Deterioration</link></style> they can be <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>. As <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> can give <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, they allow the fulfillment of <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style> goals. In <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> can let different <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> have different <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>.

In <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> the presence of usable <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> can create <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> in relations to those that do not have the <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style>. This inequality can spawn also goals of <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style>, which in turn may give rise to <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>, and even the <style="Link"><link="game-element-trading">Game Element Trading</link></style> and its associated <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style>, unless made impossible by game rules. Alternatively in can give rise to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals.

Since they can change the outcome of actions done by <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> provide a way of constructing <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style>. The change can also lead to players having an <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>, especially if players can choose between which <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> to use (a form of <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>). They may also cause problems with <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> since those in possession of <style="CurrentLink">Tools</style> may have a distinct advantage. This however also lets players cooperating to develop <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Buffs">Buffs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="collecting">Collecting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="facilitating-rewards">Facilitating Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Farming">Farming</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resource-locations">Resource Locations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="temporary-abilities">Temporary Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="vision-modes">Vision Modes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="artifact-location-proximity">Artifact-Location Proximity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cooldown">Cooldown</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deterioration">Deterioration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="endgame-quests">Endgame Quests</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="equipment-slots">Equipment Slots</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="live-action-roleplaying">Live Action Roleplaying</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-artifact-proximity">Player-Artifact Proximity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>
